chapter.title: Export &cephfs; via Samba
chapter.para: This section describes how to export &cephfs; via a Samba/CIFS share. Samba shares can be used with Windows* clients.

sect1.title: Single Gateway Example
sect1.para: In preparation for exporting a Samba share, choose an appropriate node to act as a Samba gateway. The node needs to have access to the &ceph; client network, as well as sufficient CPU, memory and networking resources.
Failover functionality can be provided with CTDB and the &sle; &hasi;. Refer to for more information on HA setup.

step.para: Make sure that a working &cephfs; already exists in your cluster. For details, see .
Create a Samba Gateway specific keyring on the &ceph; admin node and copy it to the Samba gateway node:
step.screen: &prompt.smaster;ceph auth get-or-create client.samba.gw mon 'allow r' \ osd 'allow *' mds 'allow *' -o ceph.client.samba.gw.keyring &prompt.smaster;scp ceph.client.samba.gw.keyring SAMBA_NODE:/etc/ceph/
step.para: Replace SAMBA_NODE with the name of the Samba gateway node.
The following steps are executed on the Samba gateway node. Install Samba together with the &ceph; integration package:
step.screen: &prompt.root;zypper in samba samba-ceph

step.para: Replace the default contents of the /etc/samba/smb.conf file with the following:
step.screen:
[global] netbios name = SAMBA-GW clustering = no idmap config * : backend = tdb2 passdb backend = tdbsam
[SHARE_NAME] path = / vfs objects = ceph ceph: config_file = /etc/ceph/ceph.conf ceph: user_id = samba.gw read only = no oplocks = no kernel share modes = no

tip.title: Oplocks and Share Modes
tip.para: oplocks (also known as SMB2+ leases) allow for improved performance through aggressive client caching, but are currently unsafe when Samba is deployed together with other &cephfs; clients, such as kernel mount.cephfs, FUSE, or &ganesha;.
Currently kernel share modes needs to be disabled in a share running with the &cephfs; vfs module for file serving to work properly.

important.title: Permitting Access
important.para: Since vfs_ceph does not require a file system mount, the share path is interpreted as an absolute path within the &ceph; file system on the attached &ceph; cluster. For successful share I/O, the path's access control list (ACL) needs to permit access from the mapped user for the given Samba client. You can modify the ACL by temporarily mounting via the &cephfs; kernel client and using the chmod, chown or setfacl utilities against the share path. step.para: Start and enable the Samba daemon:
step.screen: &prompt.root;systemctl start smb.service &prompt.root;systemctl enable smb.service &prompt.root;systemctl start nmb.service &prompt.root;systemctl enable nmb.service

sect1.title: High Availability Configuration

important.title: Transparent Failover Not Supported
important.para: Although a multi-node Samba + CTDB deployment is more highly available compared to the single node (see ), client-side transparent failover is not supported. Applications will likely experience a short outage on Samba gateway node failure.

sect1.para: Additionally, two floating virtual IP addresses allow clients to connect to the service no matter which physical node it is running on. 192.168.1.10 is used for cluster administration with Hawk2 and 192.168.2.1 is used exclusively for the CIFS exports. This makes it easier to apply security restrictions later.
The following procedure describes the example installation. More details can be found at .

step.para: Create a Samba Gateway specific keyring on the &smaster; and copy it to both nodes:
step.screen: &prompt.smaster;ceph auth get-or-create client.samba.gw mon 'allow r' \ osd 'allow *' mds 'allow *' -o ceph.client.samba.gw.keyring &prompt.smaster;scp ceph.client.samba.gw.keyring &si.earth;:/etc/ceph/ &prompt.smaster;scp ceph.client.samba.gw.keyring &si.mars;:/etc/ceph/

step.para: Prepare &si.earth; and &si.mars; to host the Samba service:
Make sure the following packages are installed before you proceed: ctdb, tdb-tools, and samba (needed for smb and nmb resources).
step.screen: &prompt.root;zypper in ctdb tdb-tools samba samba-ceph

step.para: Make sure the services ctdb, smb, and nmb are stopped and disabled:
step.screen: &prompt.root;systemctl disable ctdb &prompt.root;systemctl disable smb &prompt.root;systemctl disable nmb &prompt.root;systemctl stop smb &prompt.root;systemctl stop nmb

step.para: Open port 4379 of your firewall on all nodes. This is needed for CTDB to communicate with other cluster nodes.
On &si.earth; create the configuration files for Samba. They will later automatically be synchronized to &si.mars;.
In /etc/ctdb/nodes insert all nodes which contain all private IP addresses of each node in the cluster:
step.screen: &subnetI;.1 &subnetI;.2

step.para: Configure Samba. Add the following lines in the [global] section of /etc/samba/smb.conf. Use the host name of your choice in place of "CTDB-SERVER" (all nodes in the cluster will appear as one big node with this name, effectively). Add a share definition as well, consider SHARE_NAME as an example:
step.screen:
[global] netbios name = SAMBA-HA-GW clustering = yes idmap config * : backend = tdb2 passdb backend = tdbsam ctdbd socket = /var/lib/ctdb/ctdb.socket
[SHARE_NAME] path = / vfs objects = ceph ceph: config_file = /etc/ceph/ceph.conf ceph: user_id = samba.gw read only = no oplocks = no kernel share modes = no
step.para: Note that the /etc/ctdb/nodes and /etc/samba/smb.conf files need to match on all Samba gateway nodes.
Install and bootstrap the &sle; &ha; cluster.
Register the &sle; &hasi; on &si.earth; and &si.mars;.
step.screen: &prompt.earth;SUSEConnect -r ACTIVATION_CODE -e E_MAIL
&prompt.mars;SUSEConnect -r ACTIVATION_CODE -e E_MAIL

step.para: Install ha-cluster-bootstrap on both nodes:
step.screen: &prompt.earth;zypper in ha-cluster-bootstrap
&prompt.mars;zypper in ha-cluster-bootstrap

step.para: Initialize the cluster on &si.earth;:
step.screen: &prompt.earth;ha-cluster-init

step.para: Let &si.mars; join the cluster:
step.screen: &prompt.mars;ha-cluster-join -c earth

step.para: Check the status of the cluster. You should see two nodes added in cluster:
step.screen:
&prompt.earth;crm status 2 nodes configured 1 resource configured
Online: [ earth mars ]
Full list of resources:
admin-ip (ocf::heartbeat:IPaddr2): Started earth

step.para: Execute the following commands on &si.earth; to configure the CTDB resource:
step.screen: &prompt.earth;crm configure &prompt.crm.conf;primitive ctdb ocf:heartbeat:CTDB params \ ctdb_manages_winbind="false" \ ctdb_manages_samba="false" \ ctdb_recovery_lock="!/usr/lib64/ctdb/ctdb_mutex_ceph_rados_helper ceph client.samba.gw cephfs_metadata ctdb-mutex" ctdb_socket="/var/lib/ctdb/ctdb.socket" \ op monitor interval="10" timeout="20" \ op start interval="0" timeout="200" \ op stop interval="0" timeout="100" &prompt.crm.conf;primitive nmb systemd:nmb \ op start timeout="100" interval="0" \ op stop timeout="100" interval="0" \ op monitor interval="60" timeout="100" &prompt.crm.conf;primitive smb systemd:smb \ op start timeout="100" interval="0" \ op stop timeout="100" interval="0" \ op monitor interval="60" timeout="100" &prompt.crm.conf;group g-ctdb ctdb nmb smb &prompt.crm.conf;clone cl-ctdb g-ctdb meta interleave="true" &prompt.crm.conf;commit
step.para: The binary /usr/lib64/ctdb/ctdb_mutex_ceph_rados_helper in the configuration option ctdb_recovery_lock has the parameters CLUSTER_NAME CEPHX_USER RADOS_POOL RADOS_OBJECT in this order.

An extra lock-timeout parameter can be appended to override the default value used (10 seconds). A higher value will increase the CTDB recovery master failover time, a lower value may result in the recovery master being incorrectly detected as down, triggering flapping failovers.
Add a clustered IP address:
step.screen: &prompt.crm.conf;primitive ip ocf:heartbeat:IPaddr2 params ip=192.168.2.1 \ unique_clone_address="true" \ op monitor interval="60" \ meta resource-stickiness="0" &prompt.crm.conf;clone cl-ip ip \ meta interleave="true" clone-node-max="2" globally-unique="true" &prompt.crm.conf;colocation col-with-ctdb 0: cl-ip cl-ctdb &prompt.crm.conf;order o-with-ctdb 0: cl-ip cl-ctdb &prompt.crm.conf;commit
step.para: If unique_clone_address is set to true, the IPaddr2 resource agent adds a clone ID to the specified address, leading to three different IP addresses. These are usually not needed, but help with load balancing. For further information about this topic, see .
Check the result:
step.screen: &prompt.earth;crm status Clone Set: base-clone [dlm] Started: [ factory-1 ] Stopped: [ factory-0 ] Clone Set: cl-ctdb [g-ctdb] Started: [ factory-1 ] Started: [ factory-0 ] Clone Set: cl-ip [ip] (unique) ip:0 (ocf:heartbeat:IPaddr2): Started factory-0 ip:1 (ocf:heartbeat:IPaddr2): Started factory-1

step.para: Test from a client machine. On a Linux client, run the following command to see if you can copy files from and to the system:
step.screen: &prompt.root;smbclient //192.168.2.1/myshare
